Beyond Hypertree Width: Decomposition Methods Without Decompositions

Hubie Chen    Víctor Dalmau
Abstract

The general intractability of the constraint satisfaction problem has motivated the study of restrictions on this problem that permit polynomial-time solvability. One major line of work has focused on structural restrictions, which arise from restricting the interaction among constraint scopes. In this paper, we engage in a mathematical investigation of generalized hypertree width, a structural measure that has up to recently eluded study. We obtain a number of computational results, including a simple proof of the tractability of CSP instances having bounded generalized hypertree width.

1 Introduction

The constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) is widely acknowledged as a convenient framework for modelling search problems. Instances of the CSP arise in a variety of domains, including artificial intelligence, database theory, algebra, propositional logic, and graph theory. An instance of the CSP consists of a set of constraints on a set of variables; the question is to determine if there is an assignment to the variables satisfying all of the constraints. Alternatively, the CSP can be cast as the fundamental algebraic problem of deciding, given two relational structures 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B, whether or not there is a homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B. In this formalization, each relation of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A contains the tuples of variables that are constrained together, which are often called the constraint scopes, and the corresponding relation of 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B contains the allowable tuples of values that the variable tuples may take.

It is well-known that the CSP, in its general formulation, is NP-complete; this general intractability has motivated a large and rich body of research aimed at identifying and understanding restricted cases of the CSP that are polynomial-time tractable. The restrictions that have been studied can, by and large, be placed into one of two categories, which–due to the homomorphism formulation of the CSP–have become known as left-hand side restrictions and right-hand side restrictions. From a high level view, left-hand side restrictions, also known as structural restrictions, arise from prespecifying a class of relational structures 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A from which the left-hand side structure 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A must come, while right-hand side restrictions arise from prespecifying a class of relational structures ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B from which the right-hand side structure 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B must come. As this paper is concerned principally with structural restrictions, we will not say more about right-hand side restrictions than that their systematic study has origins in a classic theorem of Schaefer [21], and that recent years have seen some extremely exciting results on them (for instance [4, 5]).

The structural restrictions studied in the literature can all be phrased as restrictions on the hypergraph H⁢(𝐀)𝐻𝐀H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ) naturally arising from the left-hand side relational structure 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A, namely, the hypergraph H⁢(𝐀)𝐻𝐀H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ) with an edge {a1,…,ak}subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑘\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}\}{ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for each tuple (a1,…,ak)subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑘(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A. Let us briefly review some of the relevant results that have been obtained on structural tractability. The tractability of left-hand side relational structures having bounded treewidth was shown in the constraint satisfaction literature by Dechter and Pearl [9] and Freuder [10].111 One way to define what we mean by treewidth here is the treewidth of the graph obtained from H⁢(𝐀)𝐻𝐀H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ) by drawing an edge between any two vertices that are in the same hyperedge. Later, Dalmau et al. [8] building on ideas of Kolaitis and Vardi [19, 20] gave a consistency-style algorithm for deciding the bounded treewidth CSP. For our present purposes, it is worth highlighting that although the notion of bounded treewidth is defined in terms of tree decompositions, which can be computed efficiently (under bounded treewidth), the algorithm given by Dalmau et al. [8] does not compute any form of tree decomposition. Dalmau et al. also identified a natural expansion of structures having bounded treewidth that is tractable–namely, the structures homomorphically equivalent to those having bounded treewidth. The optimality of this latter result, in the case of bounded arity, was demonstrated by Grohe [15], who proved–roughly speaking–that if the tuples of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A are of bounded arity and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A gives rise to a tractable case of the CSP, then it must fall into the natural expansion identified by Dalmau et al. [8].

A number of papers, including [17, 16, 13, 14, 11, 7], have studied restrictions that can be applied to relational structures of unbounded arity. (Note that any class of relational structures of unbounded arity cannot have bounded treewidth.) In a survey [13], Gottlob et al. show that the restriction of bounded hypertree width [11] is the most powerful structural restriction for the CSP in that every other structural restriction studied in the literature is subsumed by it. Since this work [11, 13], whether or not there is a more general structural restriction than bounded hypertree width that ensures tractability, has been a tantalizing open question.

In this paper, we study generalized hypertree width, a structural measure for hypergraphs defined in [12] that is a natural variation of hypertree width; we call this measure coverwidth. Coverwidth is trivially upper-bounded by hypertree width, and so any class of hypergraphs having bounded hypertree width has bounded coverwidth. We define a combinatorial pebble game that can be played on any CSP instance, and demonstrate that this game is intimately linked to coverwidth (Theorem 3.2). Our study of coverwidth is conceptually simple, mathematically elegant, and relatively compact; we believe that this hints that coverwidth is in fact a natural and robust mathematical concept that may find further applications. Overall, the investigation we perform takes significant inspiration from methods, concepts, and ideas developed by Kolaitis, Vardi, and coauthors [19, 20, 8, 2] that link together CSP consistency algorithms, the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-pebble games of Kolaitis and Vardi [18], and bounded treewidth.

Using the pebble game perspective, we are able to derive a number of computational results. One is that the structural restriction of bounded coverwidth implies polynomial-time tractability; this result generalizes the tractability of bounded hypertree width. It has been independently shown by Adler et al. that the hypertree width of a hypergraph is linearly related to the coverwidth [1]. This result can be used in conjunction with the tractability of bounded hypertree width to derive the tractability of bounded coverwidth. However, we believe our proof of bounded coverwidth tractability to be considerably simpler than the known proof of bounded hypertree width tractability [11], even though our proof is of a more general result.

To describe our results in greater detail, it will be useful to identify two computational problems that every form of structural restriction gives rise to: a promise problem, and a no-promise problem. In both problems, the goal is to identify all CSP instances obeying the structural restriction as either satisfiable or unsatisfiable. In the promise problem, the input is a CSP instance that is guaranteed to obey the structural restriction, whereas in the no-promise problem, the input is an arbitrary CSP instance, and an algorithm may, on an instance not obeying the structural restriction, decline to identify the instance as satisfiable or unsatisfiable. Of course, CSPs arising in practice do not come with guarantees that they obey structural restrictions, and hence an algorithm solving the no-promise problem is clearly the more desirable. Notice that, for any structural restriction having a polynomial-time solvable promise problem, if it is possible to solve the identification problem of deciding whether or not an instance obeys the restriction, in polynomial time, then the no-promise problem is also polynomial-time solvable. For bounded hypertree width, both the identification problem and the no-promise problem are polynomial-time solvable. In fact, the survey by Gottlob et al. [13] only considers structural restrictions for which the identification problem is polynomial-time solvable, and thus only considers structural restrictions for which the no-promise problem is polynomial-time solvable.

One of our main theorems (Theorem 4.3) is that the promise problem for bounded coverwidth is polynomial-time tractable, via a general consistency-like algorithm. In particular, we show that, on an instance having bounded coverwidth, our algorithm detects an inconsistency if and only if the instance is unsatisfiable. Our algorithm, like the consistency algorithm of Dalmau et al. [8] for bounded treewidth, can be applied to any CSP instance to obtain a more constrained instance; our algorithm does not need nor compute any form of decomposition, even though the notion of coverwidth is defined in terms of decompositions!

Intriguingly, we are then able to give a simple algorithm for the no-promise problem for bounded coverwidth (Theorem 4.4) that employs the consistency-like algorithm for the promise problem. The behavior of this algorithm is reminiscent of self-reducibility arguments in computational complexity theory, and on an instance of bounded coverwidth, the algorithm is guaranteed to either report a satisfying assignment or that the instance is unsatisfiable. We believe that our results offer a direct challenge to the view of structural tractability advanced in the Gottlob et al. survey [13], since we are able to give a polynomial-time algorithm for the bounded coverwidth no-promise problem without explicitly showing that there is a polynomial-time algorithm for the bounded coverwidth identification problem.

Returning to the promise problem, we then show that the tractability of bounded coverwidth structures can be generalized to yield the tractability of structures homomorphically equivalent to those having bounded coverwidth (Theorem 4.5). This expansion of bounded coverwidth tractability is analogous to the expansion of bounded treewidth tractability carried out in [8].

In the last section of this paper, we use the developed theory as well as ideas in [6] to define a tractable class of quantified constraint satisfaction problems based on coverwidth.

We emphasize that none of the algorithms in this paper need or compute any type of decomposition, even though all of the structural restrictions that they address are defined in terms of decompositions.

Definitions.

In this paper, we formalize the CSP as a relational homomorphism problem. We review the relevant definitions that will be used. A relational signature is a finite set of relation symbols, each of which has an associated arity. A relational structure 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A (over signature σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ) consists of a universe A𝐴Aitalic_A and a relation R𝐀superscript𝑅𝐀R^{\mathbf{A}}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over A𝐴Aitalic_A for each relation symbol R𝑅Ritalic_R (of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ), such that the arity of R𝐀superscript𝑅𝐀R^{\mathbf{A}}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT matches the arity associated to R𝑅Ritalic_R. We refer to the elements of the universe of a relational structure 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A as 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-elements. When 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A is a relational structure over σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ and R𝑅Ritalic_R is any relation symbol of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ, the elements of R𝐀superscript𝑅𝐀R^{\mathbf{A}}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are called 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-tuples. Throughout this paper, we assume that all relational structures under discussion have a finite universe. We use boldface letters 𝐀,𝐁,…𝐀𝐁…\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B},\ldotsbold_A , bold_B , … to denote relational structures.

A homomorphism from a relational structure 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to another relational structure 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B is a mapping hℎhitalic_h from the universe of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to the universe of 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B such that for every relation symbol R𝑅Ritalic_R and every tuple (a1,…,ak)∈R𝐀subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑘superscript𝑅𝐀(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})\in R^{\mathbf{A}}( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it holds that (h⁢(a1),…,h⁢(ak))∈R𝐁ℎsubscript𝑎1…ℎsubscript𝑎𝑘superscript𝑅𝐁(h(a_{1}),\ldots,h(a_{k}))\in R^{\mathbf{B}}( italic_h ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , … , italic_h ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ∈ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. (Here, k𝑘kitalic_k denotes the arity of R𝑅Ritalic_R.) The constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) is to decide, given an ordered pair 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B of relational structures, whether or not there is a homomorphism from the first structure, 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A, to the second, 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B. A homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B in an instance 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B of the CSP is also called a satisfying assignment, and when a satisfying assignment exists, we will say that the instance is satisfiable.

2 Coverwidth

This section defines the structural measure of hypergraph complexity that we call coverwidth. As we have mentioned, coverwidth is equal to generalized hypertree width, which was defined in [12]. We begin by defining the notion of hypergraph.

Definition 1

A hypergraph is an ordered pair (V,E)𝑉𝐸(V,E)( italic_V , italic_E ) consisting of a vertex set V𝑉Vitalic_V and a hyperedge set E𝐸Eitalic_E. The elements of E𝐸Eitalic_E are called hyperedges; each hyperedge is a subset of V𝑉Vitalic_V.

Basic to the measure of coverwidth is the notion of a tree decomposition.

such that the following conditions hold:

  1. 1.

    V=∪i∈IXi𝑉subscript𝑖𝐼subscript𝑋𝑖V=\cup_{i\in I}X_{i}italic_V = ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Tree decompositions are generally applied to graphs, and in the context of graphs, the measure of treewidth has been heavily studied. The treewidth of a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G is the minimum of the quantity maxi∈I⁡|Xi|−1subscript𝑖𝐼subscript𝑋𝑖1\max_{i\in I}|X_{i}|-1roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - 1 over all tree decompositions of G𝐺Gitalic_G. In other words, a tree decomposition is measured based on its largest bag, and the treewidth is then defined based on the “lowest cost” tree decomposition.

The measure of coverwidth is also based on the notion of tree decomposition. In coverwidth, a tree decomposition is also measured based on its “largest” bag; however, the measure applied to a bag is the number of hyperedges needed to cover it, called here the weight.

Definition 3

A k𝑘kitalic_k-union over a hypergraph H𝐻Hitalic_H (with k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0italic_k ≥ 0) is the union e1∪…∪eksubscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑘e_{1}\cup\ldots\cup e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ … ∪ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of k𝑘kitalic_k edges e1,…,eksubscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑘e_{1},\ldots,e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of H𝐻Hitalic_H.

The empty set is considered to be the unique 00-union over a hypergraph.

Definition 4

Let H=(V,E)𝐻𝑉𝐸H=(V,E)italic_H = ( italic_V , italic_E ) be a hypergraph. The weight of a subset X⊆V𝑋𝑉X\subseteq Vitalic_X ⊆ italic_V is the smallest integer k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0italic_k ≥ 0 such that X∩(∪e∈Ee)𝑋subscript𝑒𝐸𝑒X\cap(\cup_{e\in E}e)italic_X ∩ ( ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e ∈ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e ) is contained in a k𝑘kitalic_k-union over H𝐻Hitalic_H.

We measure a tree decomposition according to its heaviest bag, and define the coverwidth of a hypergraph according to the lightest-weight tree decomposition.

Definition 5

The weight of a tree decomposition of H𝐻Hitalic_H is the maximum weight over all of its bags.

Definition 6

The coverwidth of a hypergraph H𝐻Hitalic_H is the minimum weight over all tree decompositions of H𝐻Hitalic_H.

It is straightforward to verify that the coverwidth of a hypergraph is equal to the generalized hypertree width of a hypergraph [12]. Since the generalized hypertree width of a hypergraph is always less than or equal to its hypertree width, coverwidth is at least as strong as hypertree width in that results on bounded coverwidth imply results on bounded hypertree width.

There is another formulation of tree decompositions that is often wieldy, see for instance [3].

    (V,F)𝑉𝐹(V,F)( italic_V , italic_F ) has a perfect elimination ordering, that is, an ordering v1,…,vnsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of its vertices such that for all i<j<k𝑖𝑗𝑘i<j<kitalic_i < italic_j < italic_k, if (vi,vk)subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑘(v_{i},v_{k})( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (vj,vk)subscript𝑣𝑗subscript𝑣𝑘(v_{j},v_{k})( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are edges in F𝐹Fitalic_F, then (vi,vj)subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗(v_{i},v_{j})( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is also an edge in F𝐹Fitalic_F, and

    the vertices of every hyperedge of E𝐸Eitalic_E induce a clique in (V,F)𝑉𝐹(V,F)( italic_V , italic_F ).

It is well known that the property of having a perfect elimination ordering is equivalent to being chordal. The following proposition is also well-known.

Proposition 1

Let H𝐻Hitalic_H be a hypergraph. For every tree decomposition of H𝐻Hitalic_H, there exists a scheme such that each clique of the scheme is contained in a bag of the tree decomposition. Likewise, for every scheme of H𝐻Hitalic_H, there exists a tree decomposition such that each bag of the tree decomposition is contained in a clique of the scheme.

Let us define the weight of a scheme (of a hypergraph H𝐻Hitalic_H) to be the maximum weight (with respect to H𝐻Hitalic_H) over all of its cliques. The following proposition is immediate from Proposition 1 and the definition of coverwidth, and can be taken as an alternative definition of coverwidth.

Proposition 2

The coverwidth of a hypergraph H𝐻Hitalic_H is equal to the minimum weight over all schemes of H𝐻Hitalic_H.

We now define the hypergraph associated to a relational structure. Roughly speaking, this hypergraph is obtained by “forgetting” the ordering of the 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-tuples.

Definition 8

Let 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A be a relational structure. The hypergraph associated to 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A is denoted by H⁢(𝐀)𝐻𝐀H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ); the vertex set of H⁢(𝐀)𝐻𝐀H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ) is the universe of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A, and for each 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-tuple (a1,…,ak)subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑘(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), there is an edge {a1,…,ak}subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑘\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}\}{ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in H⁢(𝐀)𝐻𝐀H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ).

We will often implicitly pass from a relational structure to its associated hypergraph, that is, we simply write 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A in place of H⁢(𝐀)𝐻𝐀H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ). In particular, we will speak of k𝑘kitalic_k-unions over a relational structure 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A.

3 Pebble Games

We now define a class of pebble games for studying the measure of coverwidth. These games are essentially equivalent to the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-pebble games defined by Kolaitis and Vardi and used to study constraint satisfaction [18, 20]. The pebble game that we use is defined as follows. The game is played between two players, the Spoiler and the Duplicator, on a pair of relational structures 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B that are defined over the same signature. Game play proceeds in rounds, and in each round one of the following occurs:

  1. 1.

    The Spoiler places a pebble on an 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-element a𝑎aitalic_a. In this case, the Duplicator must respond by placing a corresponding pebble, denoted by h⁢(a)ℎ𝑎h(a)italic_h ( italic_a ), on a 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B-element.

  2. 2.

    The Spoiler removes a pebble from an 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-element a𝑎aitalic_a. In this case, the corresponding pebble h⁢(a)ℎ𝑎h(a)italic_h ( italic_a ) on 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B is removed.

When game play begins, there are no pebbles on any 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-elements, nor on any 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B-elements, and so the first round is of the first type. We assume that the Spoiler never places two pebbles on the same 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-element, so that hℎhitalic_h is a partial function (as opposed to a relation). The Duplicator wins the game if he can always ensure that hℎhitalic_h is a projective homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B; otherwise, the Spoiler wins. A projective homomorphism (from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B) is a partial function hℎhitalic_h from the universe of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to the universe of 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B such that for any relation symbol R𝑅Ritalic_R and any tuple (a1,…,ak)∈R𝐀subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑘superscript𝑅𝐀(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})\in R^{\mathbf{A}}( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A, there exists a tuple (b1,…,bk)∈R𝐁subscript𝑏1…superscript𝑏𝑘superscript𝑅𝐁(b_{1},\ldots,b^{k})\in R^{\mathbf{B}}( italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where h⁢(ai)=biℎsubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖h(a_{i})=b_{i}italic_h ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on which hℎhitalic_h is defined.

As we mentioned, the definition of this game is based on the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-pebble game introduced by Kolaitis and Vardi [18, 20]. In the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-pebble game, the number of pebbles that the Spoiler may use is bounded by k𝑘kitalic_k, and the Duplicator need only must ensure that hℎhitalic_h is a partial homomorphism. A close relationship between this game and bounded treewidth has been identified [2].

Theorem 3.1

[2] Let 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B be relational structures. For all k≥2𝑘2k\geq 2italic_k ≥ 2, the following are equivalent.

  • •

    There is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-pebble game on 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B.

  • •

    For all relational structures 𝐓𝐓\mathbf{T}bold_T of treewidth <kabsent𝑘<k< italic_k, if there is a homomorphism from 𝐓𝐓\mathbf{T}bold_T to 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A, then there is a homomorphism from 𝐓𝐓\mathbf{T}bold_T to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B.

To relate the game that we have defined with coverwidth, we are interested in parameterized versions of the game where the weight of the pebbles that the Spoiler has in play, is bounded by a constant k𝑘kitalic_k. (Here, by “weight” we are using Definition 4.) That is, the weight of the 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-elements that have pebbles, is bounded by the constant k𝑘kitalic_k. We call this the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game. We now formalize the notion of a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game. Note that when hℎhitalic_h is a partial function, we use 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) to denote the domain of hℎhitalic_h.

Definition 9

A winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on relational structures 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B is a non-empty set H𝐻Hitalic_H of projective homomorphisms (from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B) having the following two properties.

  1. 1.

    (the “forth” property) For every h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H and 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-element a∉𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝑎𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎa\notin\mathsf{dom}(h)italic_a ∉ sansserif_dom ( italic_h ), if 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a } has weight ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k, then there exists a projective homomorphism h′∈Hsuperscriptℎ′𝐻h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_H extending hℎhitalic_h with 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h′)=𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}𝖽𝗈𝗆superscriptℎ′𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})=\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a }.

  2. 2.

    The set H𝐻Hitalic_H is closed under subfunctions, that is, if h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H and hℎhitalic_h extends h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then h′∈Hsuperscriptℎ′𝐻h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_H.

We have the following analog of Theorem 3.1.

Theorem 3.2

Let 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B be relational structures. For all k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1italic_k ≥ 1, the following are equivalent.

  • •

    There is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B.

  • •

    For all relational structures 𝐓𝐓\mathbf{T}bold_T of coverwidth ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k, if there is a homomorphism from 𝐓𝐓\mathbf{T}bold_T to 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A, then there is a homomorphism from 𝐓𝐓\mathbf{T}bold_T to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B.

Theorem 3.2 can be easily applied to show that in an instance 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B of the CSP, if the left-hand side structure has coverwidth bounded by k𝑘kitalic_k, then deciding if there is a homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B is equivalent to deciding the existence of a Duplicator winning strategy in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game.

Theorem 3.3

Let 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A be a relational structure having coverwidth ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k, and let 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B be an arbitrary relational structure. There is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B if and only if there is a homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B.

We will use this theorem in the next section to develop tractability results. Although we use Theorem 3.2 to derive this theorem, we would like to emphasize that the full power of Theorem 3.2 is not needed to derive it, as pointed out in the proof.

Proof

If there is a homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B, the Duplicator can win by always setting pebbles according the homomorphism. The other direction is immediate from Theorem 3.2 (note that we only need the forward implication and 𝐓=𝐀𝐓𝐀\mathbf{T}=\mathbf{A}bold_T = bold_A). ∎

4 The Algorithmic Viewpoint

The previous section introduced the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game. We showed that deciding a CSP instance of bounded coverwidth is equivalent to deciding if the Duplicator has a winning strategy in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game. In this section, we show that the latter property–the existence of a Duplicator winning strategy–can be decided algorithmically in polynomial time. To this end, it will be helpful to introduce the notion of a compact winning strategy.

Definition 10

A compact winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on relational structures 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B is a non-empty set H𝐻Hitalic_H of projective homomorphisms (from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B) having the following properties.

  1. 1.

    For all h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H, 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) is a k𝑘kitalic_k-union (over 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A).

  2. 2.

    For every h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H and for every k𝑘kitalic_k-union U𝑈Uitalic_U (over 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A), there exists h′∈Hsuperscriptℎ′𝐻h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_H with 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h′)=U𝖽𝗈𝗆superscriptℎ′𝑈\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})=Usansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_U such that for every v∈𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∩𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h′)𝑣𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝖽𝗈𝗆superscriptℎ′v\in\mathsf{dom}(h)\cap\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})italic_v ∈ sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∩ sansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), h⁢(v)=h′⁢(v)ℎ𝑣superscriptℎ′𝑣h(v)=h^{\prime}(v)italic_h ( italic_v ) = italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v ).

Proposition 3

In the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on a pair of relational structures 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B, the Duplicator has a winning strategy if and only if the Duplicator has a compact winning strategy.

Proof

Suppose that the Duplicator has a winning strategy H𝐻Hitalic_H. Let C𝐶Citalic_C be the set containing all functions h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H such that 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) is a k𝑘kitalic_k-union. We claim that C𝐶Citalic_C is a compact winning strategy. Clearly C𝐶Citalic_C satisfies the first property of a compact winning strategy, so we show that it satisfies the second property. Suppose h∈Cℎ𝐶h\in Citalic_h ∈ italic_C and let U𝑈Uitalic_U be a k𝑘kitalic_k-union. By the subfunction property of a winning strategy, the restriction r𝑟ritalic_r of hℎhitalic_h to 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∩U𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑈\mathsf{dom}(h)\cap Usansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∩ italic_U is in H𝐻Hitalic_H. By repeated application of the forth property, there is an extension e𝑒eitalic_e of r𝑟ritalic_r that is in H𝐻Hitalic_H and has domain U𝑈Uitalic_U, which serves as the desired h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Now suppose that the Duplicator has a compact winning strategy C𝐶Citalic_C. Let H𝐻Hitalic_H be the closure of C𝐶Citalic_C under subfunctions. We claim that H𝐻Hitalic_H is a winning strategy. It suffices to show that H𝐻Hitalic_H has the forth property. Let h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H and suppose that a𝑎aitalic_a is an 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-element where 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a } has weight ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k. Let U𝑈Uitalic_U be a k𝑘kitalic_k-union such that 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}⊆U𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎𝑈\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}\subseteq Usansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a } ⊆ italic_U. By definition of H𝐻Hitalic_H, there is a function e∈C𝑒𝐶e\in Citalic_e ∈ italic_C extending hℎhitalic_h. Apply the second property of a compact winning strategy to e𝑒eitalic_e and U𝑈Uitalic_U to obtain an e′∈Csuperscript𝑒′𝐶e^{\prime}\in Citalic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_C with domain U𝑈Uitalic_U such that for every v∈𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(e)∩𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(e′)𝑣𝖽𝗈𝗆𝑒𝖽𝗈𝗆superscript𝑒′v\in\mathsf{dom}(e)\cap\mathsf{dom}(e^{\prime})italic_v ∈ sansserif_dom ( italic_e ) ∩ sansserif_dom ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), e⁢(v)=e′⁢(v)𝑒𝑣superscript𝑒′𝑣e(v)=e^{\prime}(v)italic_e ( italic_v ) = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v ). Notice that 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)⊆𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(e)∩𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(e′)𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝖽𝗈𝗆𝑒𝖽𝗈𝗆superscript𝑒′\mathsf{dom}(h)\subseteq\mathsf{dom}(e)\cap\mathsf{dom}(e^{\prime})sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ⊆ sansserif_dom ( italic_e ) ∩ sansserif_dom ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Thus, the restriction of e′superscript𝑒′e^{\prime}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a } is in H𝐻Hitalic_H and extends hℎhitalic_h. ∎

We have just shown that deciding if there is a winning strategy, in an instance of the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game, is equivalent to deciding if there is a compact winning strategy. We now use this equivalence to give a polynomial-time algorithm for deciding if there is a winning strategy.

Theorem 4.1

For all k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1italic_k ≥ 1, there exists a polynomial-time algorithm that, given a pair of relational structures 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B, decides whether or not there is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B.

Proof

By Proposition 3, it suffices to give a polynomial-time algorithm that decides if there is a compact winning strategy. It is straightforward to develop such an algorithm based on the definition of compact winning strategy. Let H𝐻Hitalic_H be the set of all functions hℎhitalic_h such that 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) is a k𝑘kitalic_k-union (over 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A) and such that hℎhitalic_h is a projective homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B. Iteratively perform the following until no changes can be made to H𝐻Hitalic_H: for every function h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H and every k𝑘kitalic_k-union U𝑈Uitalic_U, check to see if there is h′∈Hsuperscriptℎ′𝐻h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_H such that the second property (of compact winning strategy) is satisfied; if not, remove hℎhitalic_h from H𝐻Hitalic_H. Throughout the algorithm, we have maintained the invariant that any compact winning strategy must be a subset of H𝐻Hitalic_H. Hence, if when the algorithm terminates H𝐻Hitalic_H is empty, then there is no compact winning strategy. And if H𝐻Hitalic_H is non-empty when the algorithm terminates, H𝐻Hitalic_H is clearly a compact winning strategy.

The number of k𝑘kitalic_k-unions (over 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A) is polynomial in the number of tuples in 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A. Also, for each k𝑘kitalic_k-union U𝑈Uitalic_U, the number of projective homomorphisms hℎhitalic_h with 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)=U𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑈\mathsf{dom}(h)=Usansserif_dom ( italic_h ) = italic_U from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B is polynomial in the number of tuples in 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B. Hence, the size of the original set H𝐻Hitalic_H is polynomial in the original instance. Since in each iteration an element is removed from H𝐻Hitalic_H, the algorithm terminates in polynomial time. ∎

The algorithm we have just described in the proof of Theorem 4.1 may appear to be quite specialized. However, we now show that essentially that algorithm can be viewed as a general inference procedure for CSP instances in the vein of existing consistency algorithms. In particular, we give a general algorithm called projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency for CSP instances that, given a CSP instance, performs inference and outputs a more constrained CSP instance having exactly the same satisfying assignments as the original. On a CSP instance 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B, the algorithm might detect an inconsistency, by which we mean that it detects that there is no homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B. If it does not, then it is guaranteed that there is a winning strategy for the Duplicator.

Definition 11

The projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm takes as input a CSP instance 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B, and consists of the following steps.

  • •

    Iteratively perform the following until no changes can be made: remove any 𝐁′superscript𝐁′\mathbf{B}^{\prime}bold_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-tuple (b1,…,bk)subscript𝑏1…subscript𝑏𝑘(b_{1},\ldots,b_{k})( italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) that is not a projective homomorphism.     Report an inconsistency if there are no 𝐁′superscript𝐁′\mathbf{B}^{\prime}bold_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-tuples remaining.

Theorem 4.2

For each k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1italic_k ≥ 1, the projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm, given as input a CSP instance 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B:

  • •

    runs in polynomial time,

  • •

    outputs a CSP instance 𝐀′,𝐁′superscript𝐀′superscript𝐁′\mathbf{A}^{\prime},\mathbf{B}^{\prime}bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that has the same satisfying assignments as 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B, and

  • •

    reports an inconsistency if and only if the Duplicator does not have a winning strategy in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B.

Proof

The first property is straightforward to verify. For the second property, observe that, each time a tuple is removed from 𝐁′superscript𝐁′\mathbf{B}^{\prime}bold_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the set of satisfying assignments is preserved. For the third property, observe that, associating 𝐁′superscript𝐁′\mathbf{B}^{\prime}bold_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-tuples to functions as in Definition 11, the behavior of the projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm is identical to the behavior of the algorithm in the proof of Proposition 3. ∎

By using the results presented in this section thus far, it is easy to show that CSP instances of bounded coverwidth are tractable. Define the coverwidth of a CSP instance 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B to be the coverwidth of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A. Let 𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k]𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{CSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_CSP [ sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ] be the restriction of the CSP to all instances of coverwidth less than or equal to k𝑘kitalic_k.

Theorem 4.3

For all k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1italic_k ≥ 1, the problem 𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k]𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{CSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_CSP [ sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ] is decidable in polynomial time by the projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm. In particular, on an instance of 𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k]𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{CSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_CSP [ sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ], the projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm reports an inconsistency if and only if the instance is not satisfiable.

Proof

Immediate from Theorem 3.3 and the third property of Theorem 4.2. ∎

Note that we can derive the tractability of CSP instances having bounded hypertree width immediately from Theorem 4.3.

Now, given a CSP instance that is promised to have bounded coverwidth, we can use projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency to decide the instance (Theorem 4.3). This tractability result can in fact be pushed further: we can show that there is a generic polynomial-time that, given an arbitrary CSP instance, is guaranteed to decide instances of bounded coverwidth. Moreover, whenever an instance is decided to be a “yes” instance by the algorithm, a satisfying assignment is constructed.

Theorem 4.4

For all k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1italic_k ≥ 1, there exists a polynomial-time algorithm that, given any CSP instance 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B,

  1. 1.

    outputs a satisfying assignment for 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B,

  2. 2.

    correctly reports that 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B is unsatisfiable, or

  3. 3.

    reports “I don’t know”.

The algorithm always performs (1) or (2) on an instance of 𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k]𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{CSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_CSP [ sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ].

Proof

The algorithm is a simple extension of the projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm. First, the algorithm applies the projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm; if an inconsistency is detected, then the algorithm terminates and reports that 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B is unsatisfiable. Otherwise, it initializes V𝑉Vitalic_V to be the universe A𝐴Aitalic_A of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A, and does the following:

  • •

    If V𝑉Vitalic_V is empty, terminate and identify the mapping taking each a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in Aitalic_a ∈ italic_A to the 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B-element in Ra𝐁superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑎𝐁R_{a}^{\mathbf{B}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as a satisfying assignment.

  • •

    Pick any variable v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in Vitalic_v ∈ italic_V.

  • •

    Expand the signature of 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B to include another symbol Rvsubscript𝑅𝑣R_{v}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with Rv𝐀={(v)}superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑣𝐀𝑣R_{v}^{\mathbf{A}}=\{(v)\}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { ( italic_v ) }.

  • •

    Try to find a 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B-element b𝑏bitalic_b such that when Rv𝐁superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑣𝐁R_{v}^{\mathbf{B}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is set to {(b)}𝑏\{(b)\}{ ( italic_b ) }, no inconsistency is detected by the projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm on the expanded instance.

    • –

      If there is no such 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B-element, terminate and report “I don’t know”.

    • –

      Otherwise, set Rv𝐁superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑣𝐁R_{v}^{\mathbf{B}}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to such a 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B-element, remove v𝑣vitalic_v from V𝑉Vitalic_V, and repeat from the first step using the expanded instance.

If the procedure terminates from V𝑉Vitalic_V being empty in the first step, the mapping that is output is straightforwardly verified to be a satisfying assignment.

Suppose that the algorithm is given an instance of 𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k]𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{CSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_CSP [ sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ]. If it is unsatisfiable, then the algorithm reports that the instance is unsatisfiable by Theorem 4.3. So suppose that the instance is satisfiable. We claim that each iteration preserves the satisfiability of the instance. Let 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B denote the CSP instance at the beginning of an arbitrary iteration of the algorithm. If no inconsistency is detected after adding a new relation symbol Rvsubscript𝑅𝑣R_{v}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with Rv𝐀={(v)}superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑣𝐀𝑣R_{v}^{\mathbf{A}}=\{(v)\}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { ( italic_v ) } and Rv𝐁={(b)}superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑣𝐁𝑏R_{v}^{\mathbf{B}}=\{(b)\}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { ( italic_b ) }, there must be a satisfying assignment mapping v𝑣vitalic_v to b𝑏bitalic_b by Theorem 4.3. Note that adding unary relation symbols to a CSP instance does not change the coverwidth of the instance. ∎

We now expand the tractability result of Theorem 4.3, and show the tractability of CSP instances that are homomorphically equivalent to instances of bounded coverwidth. Formally, let us say that 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A and 𝐀′superscript𝐀′\mathbf{A}^{\prime}bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are homomorphically equivalent if there is a homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐀′superscript𝐀′\mathbf{A}^{\prime}bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well as a homomorphism from 𝐀′superscript𝐀′\mathbf{A}^{\prime}bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A. Let 𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[ℋ⁢(𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k)]𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]ℋ𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{CSP}[\mathcal{H}(\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k)]sansserif_CSP [ caligraphic_H ( sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ) ] denote the restriction of the CSP to instances 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B where 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A is homomorphically equivalent to a relational structure of coverwidth less than or equal to k𝑘kitalic_k.

Theorem 4.5

For all k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1italic_k ≥ 1, the problem 𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[ℋ⁢(𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k)]𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]ℋ𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{CSP}[\mathcal{H}(\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k)]sansserif_CSP [ caligraphic_H ( sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ) ] is decidable in polynomial time by the projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm. Proof

Let 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B be a CSP instance where 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A is homomorphically equivalent to a relational structure 𝐀′superscript𝐀′\mathbf{A}^{\prime}bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of coverwidth ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k.   • •

    There is a homomorphism from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B.

  • •

    There is a homomorphism from 𝐀′superscript𝐀′\mathbf{A}^{\prime}bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B (straightforward).

  • •

    The Duplicator has a winning strategy in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on 𝐀′,𝐁superscript𝐀′𝐁\mathbf{A}^{\prime},\mathbf{B}bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_B (Theorem 3.3).

  • •

    The Duplicator has a winning strategy in the existential k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B (Theorem 3.2).

  • •

    The projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency algorithm does not report an inconsistency on 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B (Theorem 4.2).

∎

5 Quantified Constraint Satisfaction

We now sketch how the ideas given in this paper on constraint satisfaction can be combined with the ideas in [6] to yield results on quantified constraint satisfaction. Specifically, we define a notion of coverwidth for QCSPs, and show that bounded coverwidth QCSPs are tractable.

Definitions.

We first briefly define the QCSP and relevant associated notions. Coverwidth.

We now define a notion of coverwidth for quantified relational structures. This can be viewed as a generalization of the definition of coverwidth in terms of schemes, given in Proposition 2.

Definition 12

A scheme of a quantified relational structure (p,𝐀)𝑝𝐀(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ) is a scheme (V,F)𝑉𝐹(V,F)( italic_V , italic_F ) of the hypergraph H⁢(𝐀)𝐻𝐀H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ) (in the sense of Definition 2) such that (V,F)𝑉𝐹(V,F)( italic_V , italic_F ) has a perfect elimination ordering v1,…,vnsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respecting the quantifier prefix p𝑝pitalic_p in that if i<j𝑖𝑗i<jitalic_i < italic_j, then vjsubscript𝑣𝑗v_{j}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT comes after visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in p𝑝pitalic_p.

Definition 13

The coverwidth of a quantified relational structure (p,𝐀)𝑝𝐀(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ) is equal to the minimum weight (with respect to 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A) over all schemes of (p,𝐀)𝑝𝐀(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ).

The quantified k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game.

We can naturally extend the k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game, making use of ideas from [6], to define the quantified k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game. We describe the quantified k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game by defining the notion of a winning strategy for the Duplicator.

Definition 14

A winning strategy for the Duplicator in the quantified k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on (p,𝐀)𝑝𝐀(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ) and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B is a non-empty set H𝐻Hitalic_H of projective homomorphisms (from 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B) having the following properties.

  1. 1.

    For every h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H and every existentially quantified 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-element a∉𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝑎𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎa\notin\mathsf{dom}(h)italic_a ∉ sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) coming after all elements of 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ), if 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a } has weight ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k, then there exists a projective homomorphism h′∈Hsuperscriptℎ′𝐻h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_H extending hℎhitalic_h with 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h′)=𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}𝖽𝗈𝗆superscriptℎ′𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})=\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a }.

  2. 2.

    For every h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H, every 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B-element b𝑏bitalic_b, and every universally quantified 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}bold_A-element a∉𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝑎𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎa\notin\mathsf{dom}(h)italic_a ∉ sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) coming after all elements of 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ), if 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a } has weight ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k, then there exists a projective homomorphism h′∈Hsuperscriptℎ′𝐻h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_H extending hℎhitalic_h with 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h′)=𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)∪{a}𝖽𝗈𝗆superscriptℎ′𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ𝑎\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})=\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) ∪ { italic_a } and h′⁢(a)=bsuperscriptℎ′𝑎𝑏h^{\prime}(a)=bitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = italic_b.

  3. 3.

    The set H𝐻Hitalic_H is closed under subfunctions, that is, if h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in Hitalic_h ∈ italic_H and hℎhitalic_h extends h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then h′∈Hsuperscriptℎ′𝐻h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_H.

We have the following analog of Theorem 3.3.

Theorem 5.1

Let (p,𝐀)𝑝𝐀(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ) be a quantified relational structure having coverwidth ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k, and let 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B be an arbitrary relational structure. There is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the quantified k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on (p,𝐀),𝐁𝑝𝐀𝐁(p,\mathbf{A}),\mathbf{B}( italic_p , bold_A ) , bold_B if and only if there is a homomorphism from (p,𝐀)𝑝𝐀(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ) to 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{B}bold_B.

Tractability.

We let 𝖰𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k]𝖰𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{QCSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_QCSP [ sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ] denote the restriction of the QCSP to all instances (p,𝐀),𝐁𝑝𝐀𝐁(p,\mathbf{A}),\mathbf{B}( italic_p , bold_A ) , bold_B where (p,𝐀)𝑝𝐀(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ) has coverwidth less than or equal to k𝑘kitalic_k. We have the following tractability result.

Theorem 5.2

For all k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1italic_k ≥ 1, the problem 𝖰𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k]𝖰𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{QCSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_QCSP [ sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ] is decidable in polynomial time.

The algorithm for Theorem 5.2 is similar to projective k𝑘kitalic_k-consistency, but in addition to removing tuples that are not projective homomorphisms, it removes further tuples, as follows. Let A1⁢…⁢Amsubscript𝐴1…subscript𝐴𝑚A_{1}\ldots A_{m}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT … italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the quantifier blocks of the prefix p𝑝pitalic_p, and let Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an existential quantifier block. Take a tuple from the right-hand side structure, view it as a mapping h:U→B:ℎ→𝑈𝐵h:U\rightarrow Bitalic_h : italic_U → italic_B, and consider its restriction h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to A1∪…∪Aisubscript𝐴1…subscript𝐴𝑖A_{1}\cup\ldots\cup A_{i}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ … ∪ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let Y𝑌Yitalic_Y be the set of all universally quantified variables in U∩(Ai+1∪…∪Am)𝑈subscript𝐴𝑖1…subscript𝐴𝑚U\cap(A_{i+1}\cup\ldots\cup A_{m})italic_U ∩ ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ … ∪ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). If there exists any extension of h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h′)∪Y𝖽𝗈𝗆superscriptℎ′𝑌\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})\cup Ysansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∪ italic_Y that is not a projective homomorphism, then the tuple is removed. After the procedure terminates, if no inconsistency is detected, then the projective homomorphisms hℎhitalic_h of the new instance where the weight of 𝖽𝗈𝗆⁢(h)𝖽𝗈𝗆ℎ\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) is ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k≤ italic_k, is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the quantified k𝑘kitalic_k-cover game on the original instance.

We can expand the result of Theorem 5.2 by Q-homomorphic equivalence, defined in [6]. Let 𝖰𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[ℋ⁢(𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k)]𝖰𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]ℋ𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{QCSP}[\mathcal{H}(\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k)]sansserif_QCSP [ caligraphic_H ( sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ) ] denote the restriction of the QCSP to all instances (p,𝐀),𝐁𝑝𝐀𝐁(p,\mathbf{A}),\mathbf{B}( italic_p , bold_A ) , bold_B where (p,𝐀)𝑝𝐀(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ) is Q-homomorphically equivalent to a quantified relational structure that has coverwidth less than or equal to k𝑘kitalic_k.

Theorem 5.3

For all k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1italic_k ≥ 1, the problem 𝖰𝖢𝖲𝖯⁢[ℋ⁢(𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁≤k)]𝖰𝖢𝖲𝖯delimited-[]ℋ𝖼𝗈𝗏𝖾𝗋𝗐𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁𝑘\mathsf{QCSP}[\mathcal{H}(\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k)]sansserif_QCSP [ caligraphic_H ( sansserif_coverwidth ≤ italic_k ) ] is decidable in polynomial time.
